summary: This is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) staff regarding press guidance and logistics for the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell. It includes scheduling details for opening statements, notes on witness pseudonyms, and the statutory penalties Maxwell faces.

persons.name: Janis Echenberg
persons.context: SDNY staff member coordinating trial logistics and press guidance for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

persons.name: Nicholas Biase
persons.context: SDNY staff member communicating about press office attendance and trial scheduling.

persons.name: James Margolin
persons.context: SDNY contractor copied on emails regarding trial exhibits and press access.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant on trial, charged with conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein to entice and traffic minors for illegal sexual activity.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier named as Ghislaine Maxwell's co-conspirator in the charges.

persons.name: Alison Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge over U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell case in the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Damian
persons.context: Mentioned as attending the trial opening along with Margaret, likely from the government.

persons.name: Margaret

persons.name: Eric Blachman

connections.description: Maxwell is charged with conspiring with Epstein to entice minors to travel to engage in illegal sex acts.
SDNY colleagues coordinating press guidance and trial logistics via email.
Both involved in SDNY communications regarding trial exhibits and press access.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal trial of Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Jury Charge and Opening Statements in U.S. v. Maxwell
events.description: Scheduled for 9:30 a.m., includes jury charge followed by opening statements in the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Final Pretrial Conference
events.description: Held for U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell before Judge Alison Nathan.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell faced six charges including conspiracy to entice minors, transportation of minors, and sex trafficking of minors, with statutory maximum penalties ranging from 5 to 40 years in prison.
The court granted a government motion allowing several witnesses, including alleged victims, to testify under pseudonyms to protect their identities.
Opening statements in U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell were scheduled for November 26, 2021, at 9:30 a.m. before Judge Alison Nathan.
Government exhibits for the trial were provided exclusively through an SDNY file share, requiring media to establish access accounts.
The document reveals internal SDNY coordination for press and logistical arrangements during the high-profile trial.
